subject: Set Resource Name based on dbus path
commitMessage:
Set Resource Name based on dbus path

Use getResourceName to convert resource id to resource name.
- Chassis
- FirmwareInventory
- Storage
- StorageController
- Processor

Mockup Reference: https://redfish.dmtf.org/redfish/mockups/v1/1101

Use the Resource Id without the index as the resource name.

Tested:
Redfish Validator Passed. No changes to the redfish tree expect for the
Name property.

```
$ wget -qO- http://localhost:80/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis_1
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis_1",
  "@odata.type": "#Chassis.v1_14_0.Chassis",
  "ChassisType": "RackMount",
  "Id": "chassis_1",
  "Name": "chassis",
  ...
}
```

Does not affect Id that does not have the `_$index` format.
```
$ wget -qO- http://localhost:80/redfish/v1/Systems/system/Processors/cpu0
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system/Processors/cpu0",
  "@odata.type": "#Processor.v1_11_0.Processor",
  "Id": "cpu0",
  "MaxSpeedMHz": 0,
  "Name": "cpu0",
  ...
}
```

Change-Id: I76e65f4aae979365266ebb38525c4ac45298737b
Signed-off-by: Willy Tu <wltu@google.com>

Validator had a few warnings due to some dbus objects leaving the PrettyName property empty. Do you have any plans to check for empty strings to avoid that? Is the onus on us to make sure the property is filled or is empty strings ok?

*** /redfish/v1/Systems/system/Processors/gv100card1

Name: Empty string found - Services should omit properties if not supported
	 PASS

Ed, any concern with this one? 
I think this is the direction to go

Patch Set 20:

> Patch Set 20:
> 
> Ed, any concern with this one? 
> I think this is the direction to go

Considering that "Name" is the property that most clients should be using to key off their URI decisions (not id like most clients erroneously use) this has some far reaching consequences.  This means that EM and phosphor-dbus-interfaces names are now part of the compatibility boundary, which seems like something that's a little scary, considering the interface is called "Pretty name" which I would assume most people translate as "human readable name", not "machine readable name".  That might be ok, but I want to understand the reprocussions of that, and I haven't had a chance to look into that.  Also, if we're going to enforce this new interface on every new inventory item, that's going to cause consequences for our mapper lookups, which needs something like this:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-objmgr/+/47317

To avoid making all of our inventory lookups one dbus call slower when we do this.  This patchset currently avoids this issue by assuming that the PrettyName property is hosted on the same connection as the item.(CPU/Drive, ect) interface, which isn't always valid.

In addition, Entity-manager enabled systems don't currently fill out PrettyName, so there's consequences for possibly breaking those systems as well.

In short, in terms of overall direction, I think this is an ok path, but there's a lot of work to do before this can merge.  Ideally the points above would be called out in the commit message.

Just to confirm (I'm not familiar with everything), is it true that there is only 1 service that matches this prettyName? or will that be an issue if there are multiple services with the same prettyName?

I think it is possible that multiple services can have prettyName. But I am assuming that the one that actually include it will be the one that we want.

I am assuming that prettyName is only included in the service that we care about. Maybe that's wrong assumption to make.

Do you think it is necessary that we add something to check whether there are multiple services with the same PrettyName? I mean if that's not what we expect, probably we should log that. I'm thinking about a wrong service with the same PrettyName is used.
At that point, I think we need to clean up the service instead then.
Actually, I will force it to have only one service that expose the path.
TODO(wltu): Add pretty name for more devices!
Done
Cool! Can you add a bit more about how this should work? E.g. sentence about if PrettyName isn't found and following back to the resource using a hardcoded Name.
yep, I'll add more implementation details. I think I need to restructure it can be used to used by all resources. Right now it dependent of other dbus calls... this should be independent.
Done
Do you use the PrettyName as a part of a redfish resource ID? Will the property be unique through all entities? Image that you have multiple drives with the same `PrettyName`.

PrettyName is just the Name of the resource.

The Id is still the last part of the object path.
Done

is this is the return of GetObject? The standard type is a map?https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/architecture/object-mapper.md#getobject
If so, I am wondering why it works when passing in a vector container.

yeah, the output is a vector at the outer level as expected.

It should be right,
```
array [
      dict entry(
         string "xyz.openbmc_project.Hwmon-1025936882.Hwmon1"
         array [
            string "xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Threshold.Critical"
            string "xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Threshold.Warning"
            string "xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Value"
         ]
      )
   ]
```

I think you missed the first array?

When converted to c++.
```
vector [
      pair(
         string "xyz.openbmc_project.Hwmon-1025936882.Hwmon1"
         vector [
            string "xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Threshold.Critical"
            string "xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Threshold.Warning"
            string "xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Value"
         ]
      )
   ]
```
Ack

[I am not familiar with bmcweb] interfaces should contain xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item. first find the service that implement object path with the interface and then query the property under that interface.

The `interfaces` in here is just the device/resource that you are looking for. It doesn't have to be `xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item`. It is like
`xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Drive` or like `xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Processor`. It does not have to contain Inventory.Item.

Then the next query will try to look for `xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item` which will have `PrettyName` (This may fail). If you include Item in `interfaces` then it will alway pass if you get to that point.

GetObject may return a service without`xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item`. Then it will send useless calls to DBUS to get the property. 

But this will not block anything, as the code handles errors
Does this have any impact to current systems?  I suspect a number of systems will see the Name field change, which, while it seems appropriate, we should call out explicitly.

Yeah, this will affect all systems if the PrettyName property is exists already. I will add some comment on this.

Maybe I should add an option to enable this instead of forcing people to update the Name.

I am not exactly sure how this can/will affect other systems, given that the default names are kind of just there with not much detail.

extra dbus read for every chassis. 

Use the id -> name for free.

More testing needed than that.  Ensuring that the names are correct and fall back in the appropriate places is also required.

Also, we need to measure the performance impact of doing 2 extra dbus calls per API.

I have added some example for the redfish calls for the new change (with and without the PrettyName property).

I also added some timing information on before the after making the bmcweb change. Not sure how useful it is tho.
Ack
As written, this is going to do an extra dbus call.  Considering most of these APIs already call getSubTree of some form, I suspect we need to reduce the scope of this helper code down.

I have it setup that way before. Moved it all in the helper function to make sure all dependences are met.

I'll add a new getSubTree call for the ones that does not have it already and clean up this one.
I have cleaned it up a bit more now to remove the extra dbus call.
Done

Lifetime issue.  name is a pointer, which might be freed by the time this lambda runs.  Generally it's recommended to parse out what you need into the base elements (strings/int ect), then pass those by value, as you've done with path (references automatically turn to values when passed through a lambda).

I suspect this function shouldn't be accepting a json object at all.  Looking at your usage, a json pointer object MIGHT be called for, but I haven't looked down that path in depth.


As written, if line 46 (or any of the other errors get hit) the response object is left with something like

"Name": null

Because the value was never filled in.  While this is an error path, it's not a pattern we want to continue.  Moving to json pointer (which is essentially a fancy json path spec) would fix that by ensuring that the value is only filled in once the method has succeeded.
I have refactored the code to use `nlohmann::json_pointer<nlohmann::json>` instead now.
Done

As mentioned previously, I would've expected to be using this call to the mapper to be "doing the work" that's being done in your helper function.  I suspect it already has the information you need, given it's finding the Item interfaces.
Done. I have cleaned it up now to remove the extra dbus call.
avoid empty PrettyName

This shouldn't be throwing errors on multiple services.

We can just loop through to find the first one that have

```
`xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item`
```
Done

This is an example of what I'm talking about in the top level comment.  You're currently relying on the mapper call, which searched on the interfaces: "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Board",
                "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Chassis"

Then using that as a proxy to lookup The item interface.  That might be correct in some cases, but definitely not all.  You should be asking the mapper to look up interfaces like this.

This looks to be an issue on all of these.

I am a bit confused on this comment.

I guess I was confused by what you said in https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43967/9/redfish-core/lib/chassis.hpp#450. I thought we want the mapper to do the work for us and limit the dbus calls?

So do we want it as a separate dbus call (depending on if it is appropriate)?

> I am a bit confused on this comment.
> 
> I guess I was confused by what you said in https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43967/9/redfish-core/lib/chassis.hpp#450. I thought we want the mapper to do the work for us and limit the dbus calls?

yes, we do.

> 
> So do we want it as a separate dbus call (depending on if it is appropriate)?

NYes and no.  We want a single mapper call (asking for all interfaces) then spread out to multiple connection calls.

ok, I'll look at it a bit more. I found some more issues. The mapper call that I used does not gurantee that the Inventory.Item is there.

There are also some issue when multiple services expose the same object path, it resulted in error right now, but it really shouldn't.

I think I have addressed it now.

So that `getPrettyName` only take in the service name and object path and utilizes the mapper from other place to look for the one we care about.

decode id -> Name.

Id is
warhog_1
warhog_2
warhog_3

Want all of them to be 
Name=Warthog

PrettyName is suppose to be unique.

---

Maybe just strip the number

"_\d+"

for Name.

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/include/dbus_utility.hpp
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/tree/master/include/ut
Yep.  Looking at the mockups for this stuff (specifically the bladed server mockup), it looks like all the nodes follow the pattern of "ID" contains the index, "Name" does not.  Lets do that.

https://redfish.dmtf.org/redfish/mockups/v1/1101

Done.

> Yep.  Looking at the mockups for this stuff (specifically the bladed server mockup), it looks like all the nodes follow the pattern of "ID" contains the index, "Name" does not.  Lets do that.

Do we have anything in the spec ? Or just the mockup ?

Why did we move away from using PrettyName? 
I thought that was the point of PrettyName, a human readable name

https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0266_1.14.0.pdf#page=81

The spec mentioned that the Name is not required to be unique.

Also, moving away from PrettyName to reduce the extra dbus call since the object path is given to us already. I also heard that Ed mentioned that PrettyName is suppose to be unique?

Entity-manager and bmcweb have never implemented PrettyName which is supposed to be a user facing name, and generally should include a unique identifier (ie, you shouldn't have two drives with PrettyName "Drive").  Redfish Name field is different than pretty name in that it's not really meant to be user facing as an identifier of an instance, more that it's an identifier of a class of resource, and can be used in an API context to determine which entry in the collection you need.

This patchset came about because clients were trying to determine the "Name" of a given thing, and basically were hardcoding in this same logic to strip the _<number> from the end to determine the "Name" of the device, which they shouldn't have to do given the redfish spec.


From reading the redfish spec, "Name" is intended to be the name of the device, and not unique.  MemberId, is supposed to be unique, as is Id.

Interestingly, I think we're in violation of the spec on member ID, 
"For services supporting Redfish v1.6 or higher, this value shall contain the zero-based array index."

We probably need to look at that field next.
You're changing ID here, not name.  Is this what you meant to do?  as written, this looks wrong.
nope. Thanks. Should replace "Name" with this instead.
Tested?

Done. Just did a Redfish Validator tests. Passed since it only changed Name.

Also added some example.
